Posts.Content: ABeautifulSunset wrote: So, once again my doctor is suggesting I enroll in this clinical trial. I am currently on Ibrance and letrozole, with stable bone mets. They want to add keytruda to see if the stable mets will disappear on the new protocol. Here is my dilemma. 1. I currently already drive for one hour in each direction every four weeks for labs and my xgeva shot. Now I would have to go every three weeks. Keytruda is an infusion that takes thirty minutes to administer. 2. My side effects are currently tolerable. Not perfect, but I certainly don't want to deal with MORE possible side effects. 3. I've been on this combo for 18 months (I think 22 months is the average time to fail). I've never been NED on this combo, although I have been NED in the past. So,my time may be running out on this protocol. Adding an immunotherapy could potentially give me a nice boost. 4. I do have the option of radiating a single bone met, which could also potentially take me to NED, but radiation has its own side effects, and it won't help me systemically. 5. I COULD wait until I have some progression, and then decide to try it. I believe the trial will continue enrolling for another year. But, of course I would rather not progress. I would love some input from my community. Here is the link to the trial. https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/results/NCT027... Posts.Content: ABeautifulSunset wrote: Hi. I was diagnosed stage 4 off the bat 3 1/2 years ago. At that time I only told a very few people that it was stage 4. I was NED until recently. Now I have to decide if I tell people that it has come back. If I do, this will be the first time for them hearing I am stage 4, and they will definitely have strong reactions. My dilemma is, if I don't tell anyone, I cant really talk to anyone about it, or they might not understand why I am down, or not feeling well. At the same time, I don't want to deal with the reactions of people, and I don't want to bum out the room. And I don't want people looking at me like I'm going to die, although sometimes a little sympathy along those lines would be nice. You see I am very conflicted. Does anyone have any advice on this? Posts.Content: ABeautifulSunset wrote: Ouch! I had CyberKnife treatment to c7 spine two weeks ago. I was misled into thinking there would be no collateral tissue damage. My throat is so sore, it hurts to swallow, and I can't eat (without pain). Dr put me on some pain and coating meds, but there seems to be no let up. Does anyone here have experience with this? I amwondering how long I'm going to suffer before I start getting some relief. ☹️ “Sunsets are proof that endings can be beautiful too.” Chemotherapy Gemzar (gemcitabine) Chemotherapy Xeloda (capecitabine) Targeted Therapy Afinitor (everolimus) Targeted Therapy Afinitor (everolimus) Chemotherapy Doxil (doxorubicin) Targeted Therapy Chemotherapy Chemotherapy Chemotherapy Xeloda (capecitabine) Targeted Therapy Radiation Therapy External: Breast, Chest wall, Bone Chemotherapy TAC Targeted Therapy Ibrance (palbociclib) Surgery Mastectomy; Reconstruction (left): Fat grafting, Silicone implant, Tissue expander placement; Reconstruction (right): Fat grafting, Silicone implant, Tissue expander placement Hormonal Therapy Aromasin (exemestane), Faslodex (fulvestrant), Femara (letrozole) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: ABeautifulSunset wrote: Ok. Two months ago I started doxil after my markers, always consistent with my disease, rose a bit and my PET showed three very small spots on liver.the next month my CEA quadrupled, to a number i had never seen before. Tumor flare? Maybe. Another month goes by. I'm completely asymptomatic. I feel great. I go for my third doxil cycle. CEA has doubled again. But I have no symptoms, no pain, my liver isnot enlarged and every single blood panel result is normal. I am doing another PET next week. Even my ONC Seems confused. Any thoughts? “Sunsets are proof that endings can be beautiful too.” Chemotherapy Gemzar (gemcitabine) Chemotherapy Xeloda (capecitabine) Targeted Therapy Afinitor (everolimus) Targeted Therapy Afinitor (everolimus) Chemotherapy Doxil (doxorubicin) Targeted Therapy Chemotherapy Chemotherapy Chemotherapy Xeloda (capecitabine) Targeted Therapy Radiation Therapy External: Breast, Chest wall, Bone Chemotherapy TAC Targeted Therapy Ibrance (palbociclib) Surgery Mastectomy; Reconstruction (left): Fat grafting, Silicone implant, Tissue expander placement; Reconstruction (right): Fat grafting, Silicone implant, Tissue expander placement Hormonal Therapy Aromasin (exemestane), Faslodex (fulvestrant), Femara (letrozole) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Confusing result ABeautifulSunset ABeautifulSunset

Posts.Content: ABeautifulSunset wrote: For the last 18 months David Bowie has known that he was dying. He kept that information private, while spending his final months doing what he'd done his whole life — making outrageously original, beautiful, complicated art. He made a gorgeous album. He created a show, playing right now in New York. And then he released his final videojust a few days before he died — on his 69th birthday. Can you imagine, to be making art like this right up to the moment of your death? How do you do that? How do you BE that? To work with your death so imaginatively, in order to perfectly time out the last beats of your life? What a magnificent creature of creation, right to the end. From the beginning, this was a man who showed us how to do life differently than anyone had ever done it before, and now look how he has done death. I am truly inspired to live my life fully and keep moving forward, regardless of, or in spite of, an expiration date. “Sunsets are proof that endings can be beautiful too.” Chemotherapy Gemzar (gemcitabine) Chemotherapy Xeloda (capecitabine) Targeted Therapy Afinitor (everolimus) Targeted Therapy Afinitor (everolimus) Chemotherapy Doxil (doxorubicin) Targeted Therapy Chemotherapy Chemotherapy Chemotherapy Xeloda (capecitabine) Targeted Therapy Radiation Therapy External: Breast, Chest wall, Bone Chemotherapy TAC Targeted Therapy Ibrance (palbociclib) Surgery Mastectomy; Reconstruction (left): Fat grafting, Silicone implant, Tissue expander placement; Reconstruction (right): Fat grafting, Silicone implant, Tissue expander placement Hormonal Therapy Aromasin (exemestane), Faslodex (fulvestrant), Femara (letrozole) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: ABeautifulSunset wrote: So, I've just started taking CBD oil, in a 1000 mg 100% CBD isolate and fractional coconut oil tincture. A friend of mine has recommended a CBD Oil (sublingual spray) that is 1500 mgs of CBD, but then added is a hemp seed extract that is high in CBD value and a small amount of full hemp oil, as a base. The total THC added from that base is 0.03%. My question is does anyone know if the delivery of the oil makes it work better? That is the claim they're making, anyway..that theirs is a more pure “whole" oil. Or might they just really be the same? Thanks. Posts.Content: ABeautifulSunset wrote: Hi ladies. My liver has progressed to a dangerous point. I will try y90 to try to control the numerous diffused and solid tumors. Both lobes affected. As soon as Y90 is complete, the plan is Abraxane (although I'm getting a second opinion on that). I'm looking for you who have done Y90. What did you follow with? How long until liver Mets returned or progressed? Thanks.
